title: What is Programming?
simplifierConcept:
Imagine you're teaching a robot to make a sandwich. You can't just say "make me lunch" – the robot needs EXACT steps: pick up bread, put on peanut butter, put on jelly, combine slices. That's programming! You're giving a computer step-by-step instructions in a language it understands.

C# (pronounced "See-Sharp") is one of those languages. It's like English, but much more precise and rule-based. When you write C# code, you're telling the computer exactly what to do, one instruction at a time.
coderExample:
// This is your first C# program!
Console.WriteLine("Hello, World!");

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Two slashes create a 'comment' – notes for humans that the computer ignores. Use these to explain your code!
This is like saying "Computer, speak!" It tells the computer to display text on the screen.
The text inside quotes is the MESSAGE you want to display. It must be in quotes so C# knows it's text, not code.
The semicolon is like a period at the end of a sentence. It tells C#: "This instruction is complete!"

challenge.instructions: Your challenge: Change the message to display YOUR name instead of 'Hello, World!'. For example, if your name is Alex, make it say 'Hello, Alex!'
challenge.starterCode:
// Change the message below to say your name!
Console.WriteLine("Hello, World!");
challenge.solutionCode:
// Change the message below to say your name!
Console.WriteLine("Hello, Alex!");
challenge.hint: Keep the Console.WriteLine part the same – just change the text between the quotes!
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting the semicolon (;) at the end – C# will complain with an error!
Removing the quotes (") around the text – the quotes are required!
Misspelling Console or WriteLine – capitalization matters in C#!
